title: About
text: Studying a double major of Sports Media and Communications and Advertising and Public Relations with a double minor in Women and Gender Studies and Communication, Emily Robinson hopes to move to Boston, MA. after graduation in May 2026. Emily holds an internship with HuskerVision and works at the Campus Recreation Center as a Strength Supervisor.

title: About
text: Studying a double major of Sports Media and Communications and Advertising and Public Relations with a double minor in Women and Gender Studies and Communication, Emily Robinson hopes to move to Boston, MA. after graduation in May 2026. Emily holds an internship with HuskerVision and works at the Campus Recreation Center as a Strength Supervisor.

title: Are The Chicago Cubs Dominating The MLB?
text:
The 2025 MLB season has been full of surprises, but one thing is certain: the Chicago Cubs are proving they are a team to watch. With a potent offense, the toughest schedule to start the season, and a solid ranking of fifth despite these challenges, the Cubs have earned the right to be considered serious contenders for the playoffs and beyond.
To fully understand where the Chicago Cubs sit in comparison to other teams in the MLB, we must first look at the incredible numbers that their offense is putting up.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(lubridate)
library(waffle)

df <- read_csv("Cubs2 - Sheet1.csv")

team_results <- df %>%
  filter(!is.na(`W/L`), !is.na(Team)) %>%
  mutate(Result = if_else(`W/L` == "W", "Win", "Loss")) %>%
  count(Team, Result)

win_order <- team_results %>%
  filter(Result == "Win") %>%
  arrange(desc(n)) %>%
  pull(Team)

team_results <- team_results %>%
  mutate(Team = factor(Team, levels = win_order))

waffle_data <- team_results %>%
  group_by(Team) %>%
  mutate(
    pct = round(n / sum(n) * 100),
    label = paste(Result, pct)
  ) %>%
  ungroup()

ggplot(waffle_data, aes(fill = Result, values = pct)) +
  geom_waffle(n_rows = 10, size = 0.33, color = "white") +
  facet_wrap(~ Team, scales = "free") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Win" = "#B0E0E6", "Loss" = "#FFA07A")) +
  labs(
    title = "Cubs Climb Back To The Top 5",
    subtitle = "The Chicago Cubs haven't been in the top 5 since 2020.",
    fill = "Result",
    caption = "Source: Baseball-Reference.com | Visualization by Emily Robinson"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 4) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10, face = "italic"),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 9, face = "plain"),
    legend.title = element_text(size = 10, face = "bold"),
    legend.text = element_text(size = 9),
    strip.text = element_text(size = 8, face = "bold"),
    legend.position = "bottom",
    axis.title = element_blank(),
    axis.text = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks = element_blank()
  )









However, their rank only proves how they really are stealing the show. While upholding a spot in the top 5, they are facing higher-level competition within their regular season schedule compared to, let’s say, the Los Angeles Dodgers that are holding a solid first place ranking but by facing easier teams to beat. Facing 30 games against teams that have winning percentages over .500, the Chicago Cubs have a record of 17-12 in those games. So basically they are proving that they have the best record against teams with the best records.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(lubridate)

ChicagoCubs <- read_csv("Cubs - Sheet1.csv")

ChicagoCubs <- ChicagoCubs %>%
  select(Date, Opponent, OpponentsWinningPCT) %>%
  mutate(
    Date = mdy(Date),
    Above500 = ifelse(OpponentsWinningPCT > 0.500, "Above .500", "Below or Equal .500")
  )

ggplot(ChicagoCubs, aes(x = Date, y = OpponentsWinningPCT)) +
  geom_line(group = 1, color = "gray70", linewidth = 1) +
  geom_point(aes(color = Above500), size = 3) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0.500, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray40") +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("Above .500" = "#B0E0E6", "Below or Equal .500" = "#FFA07A")) +
  labs(
    title = "The Cubs Fought the Toughest Schedule",
    subtitle = "30 of the Cubs' first opponents had winning records",
    x = "Date",
    y = "Opponents' Winning Percentages",
    color = "Opponent Record",
    caption = "Source: MLB.com | Visualization by Emily Robinson"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 13, face = "italic"),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
    legend.title = element_text(size = 12),
    legend.text = element_text(size = 10)
  )









Next, let’s talk about the Cubs’ offense. The reason that they are leading the league while having the toughest schedule out of anyone is due to their offensive firepower. Their lineup is a well-oiled machine, with consistent performances across the board in key areas like RBI’s, Home Runs, and total Hits. By holding their own against the toughest teams in the league, they have proved how capable they are of outscoring any team in a playoff series. The Cubs’ ability to generate runs and put pressure on pitchers will be crucial as they push towards the rest of the regular season and into post-season.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(rvest)
library(ggrepel)
library(dplyr)

teamsurl <- "https://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/majors/2025.shtml"

teams <- teamsurl |>
  read_html() |>
  html_nodes(xpath = '//*[@id="teams_standard_batting"]') |>
  html_table(header = FALSE)

teams_df <- teams[[1]]

teamsrenamed <- teams_df |> 
  rename(
    Team = X1, 
    Players = X2, 
    Age = X3, 
    Runs = X4, 
    GamesPlayed = X5, 
    PlateAppearances = X6, 
    AtBats = X7, 
    Hits = X9, 
    DoublesHit = X10, 
    TriplesHit = X11, 
    HR = X12, 
    RBI = X13, 
    StolenBases = X14, 
    CaughtStealing = X15, 
    Walks = X16, 
    Strikeouts = X17, 
    TotalBases = X20, 
    OBandSluggingPCT = X21, 
    OPS = X22, 
    DoublePlays = X24, 
    HitByPitch = X25, 
    SacrificeHits = X26, 
    SacrificeFlies = X27, 
    IntBasesOnBalls = X28, 
    RunnersLeftOnBase = X29
  )

teamsrenamed <- teamsrenamed %>%
  mutate(across(c(Runs, RBI, HR, Hits), as.numeric))

top10_runs <- teamsrenamed %>%
  arrange(desc(Runs)) %>%
  slice_head(n = 10) %>%
  mutate(TotalOffense = Runs + RBI + HR + Hits)

top10_long <- top10_runs %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(RBI, HR, Hits), names_to = "Stat", values_to = "Value") %>%
  mutate(Team = fct_reorder(Team, TotalOffense))

ggplot(top10_long, aes(x = Team, y = Value, fill = Stat)) +
  geom_col(position = "stack") +
  coord_flip() +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c(
    "RBI" = "#8FBC8F",   
    "HR" = "#FF5",    
    "Hits" = "#B0E0E6"   
  )) +
  labs(
    title = "Chicago Cubs Has The Best Offense in 2025",
    subtitle = "They lead in total offense in the top 10 MLB teams",
    x = "Team",
    y = "Total",
    fill = "Stat",
    caption = "Source: Baseball-Reference.com | By Emily Robinson"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 13, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 11, face = "italic"),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 9), 
  )

title: Did Caitlin Clark’s Rookie Season Transform the Indiana Fever?
text:
Despite the Indiana Fever finishing their 2024 season with a not-great record of 20-20, Caitlin Clark, the number one WNBA draft pick of 2024, averaged 19.2 points per game, proving her impact beyond wins and losses.
Coming off of 4 years at the University of Iowa, Clark was a household name. Objectively, Clark is a sharp point guard who’s three pointer shots were a trustworthy source of success for the Hawkeyes. Now in the WNBA, it’s debated across the sports world whether or not Caitlin Clark is as crucial to her team in her professional career as she was in college, leading the Hawkeyes to a record of 31-7 in 2023.
To fully understand her influence, we start with her general stats. Interestingly enough, Clark’s rookie year statistics are similar to the top veteran players in the WNBA.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(wehoop)
library(RColorBrewer)

players <- read_csv("wnba_players_stats.csv")

rookies_2024 <- players %>%
  select(Player, PTS, AST, REB)

clark_stats <- rookies_2024 %>%
  filter(Player == "Caitlin Clark")

rookies_2024_long <- rookies_2024 %>%
  gather(key = "Stat", value = "Value", PTS, AST, REB)

top_15_rookies <- rookies_2024 %>%
  group_by(Player) %>%
  summarise(Total_PTS = sum(PTS, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  top_n(10, Total_PTS) %>%
  select(Player)

rookies_top_15 <- rookies_2024 %>%
  filter(Player %in% top_15_rookies$Player)

rookies_top_15_long <- rookies_top_15 %>%
  gather(key = "Stat", value = "Value", PTS, AST, REB)

rookies_top_15_long <- rookies_top_15_long %>%
  mutate(Player_Color = ifelse(Player == "Caitlin Clark", "Caitlin Clark", "Other Players"))

team_colors <- c("Caitlin Clark" = "gold", "Other Players" = "#A9A9A9")

ggplot(rookies_top_15_long, aes(x = Player, y = Value, fill = Player_Color)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge", width = 0.7) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +  
  geom_text(aes(x="Caitlin Clark", y=20, label="19.2"), color="black") +
  labs(
    title = "Caitlin Clark Dominates the Top 10",  
    subtitle = "Rookie Clark points per game average compares to veteran WNBA players",  
    caption = "Source: herhoopstats.com | By Emily Robinson",
    y = "Average Points Per Game",  
    x = "Top WNBA Players 2024"  
  ) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = team_colors) +  # Apply custom colors
  theme(
    axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1, size = 12, color = "black"),  
    axis.title.x = element_text(size = 14, color = "black"),  
    axis.title.y = element_text(size = 14, color = "black"),  
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold", color = "black"),  
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14, color = "black"),  
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "grey80", linetype = "dashed"),  
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(), 
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = NA)  
  ) +
  guides(fill = FALSE) 









We see that Caitlin Clark sits competitively in the top 10 point-collectors in the WNBA. Her average is similar to two-time gold medalist, Jewell Loyd’s, who was drafted to the WNBA in 2015 by the Seattle Storm. Clark sits only slightly behind Breanna Stewart, three-time gold medalist. Stewart was the first overall pick in the 2016 WNBA draft by the Seattle Storm. So why should we care? Let’s look at the season that Indiana had in 2024.


Code
IndianaFever <- read_csv("team_score.csv")

IndianaFever <- IndianaFever %>%
  select(game_date, Score, `W/L`) %>%
  mutate(`W/L` = factor(`W/L`, levels = c("W", "L")))  

ggplot(IndianaFever, aes(x = game_date, y = Score)) +
  geom_line(color = "gray40", size = 1) +  
  geom_point(aes(color = `W/L`), size = 3) +  
  scale_color_manual(values = c("W" = "green", "L" = "red")) +
  
  labs(
    title = "Clark Takes Off While The Fever Remains Mid",
    subtitle = "Despite Clark's individual success, the Fever found themselves stuck.",
    caption = "Source: herhoopstats.com | By Emily Robinson",
    x = "Game Date",
    y = "Team Score",
    color = "Game Result"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10, angle = 90, hjust = 1),
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold")
  )









The Fever had just as many losses as wins in 2024. A 20-20 record doesn’t seem that great when it places them 6th in the league out of 12 teams. Except for the fact that the Fever finished 2024 with their best season record since 2012. The Fever qualified for the playoffs in 2024. That’s the first time since 2016. Now let’s see what exactly changed that boosted the Indiana Fever to have such a, relatively, great season in 2024.


Code
IndianaFever <- read_csv("team_score.csv") %>%
  select(Score, points, `W/L`) %>%
  mutate(
    Rest_of_Team = Score - points,  
    win = if_else(`W/L` == "W", "Win", "Loss")  
  )


IndianaFever <- IndianaFever %>%
  filter(!is.na(points), !is.na(win), !is.na(Score))

ggplot(IndianaFever, aes(x = Score, y = points, size = win, color = win)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.7) +
  scale_size_manual(values = c("Loss" = 4, "Win" = 10)) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("Win" = "green", "Loss" = "red")) +

  labs(
    title = "Caitlin Controls The Fever's Numbers",
    subtitle = "The Fever can't make up for it when Clark doesn't put up her usual points.",
    caption = "Source: herhoopstats.com | By Emily Robinson",
    
    x = "Indiana Fever's Final Score",
    y = "Caitlin Clark's Points",
    size = "Game Result",
    color = "Game Result"
  ) +
  
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold")
  )









The games that Caitlin Clark scored more points in, the team projected success. The games that Clark had less points scored individually, the team was more often to lose. If we were to base our expectations of the Indiana Fever’s future seasons, I’d say as long as they have Caitlin Clark as a trustworthy point guard, it’s only up from here.
